Variations.condition: Community-acquired in previously healthy patient, (excluding abdominal or pelvic source)
Variations.organisms: Likely Organisms: Staph. aureus, Strep. pneumoniae, Neisseria. meningitidis, Step. pyogenes (Group A strep), Occasionally Gram-negative bacilli.
Variations.antimicrobial:
Antimicrobial & Dosage: Flucloxacillin 2g iv qds
Plus
Cefotaxime 2g iv qds
+/-
Gentamicin 5mg/kg/day iv od
Variations.alternative:
Alternative Antimicrobial: Penicillin allergy (non anaphylaxis):
Vancomycin 15mg/kg iv bd
Plus
Cefotaxime 2g iv qds
+/-
Gentamicin 5mg/kg/day iv od
Variations.comments:
Comments: Perform full septic screen. Always take blood cultures first (minimum 2 sets).
Refer to Connolly Hospital Surviving Sepsis Guidelines Seek advice from Consultant Microbiologist if in doubt or in setting of penicillin anaphylaxis

Variations.condition: Community-acquired if intra- abdominal source suspected
Variations.organisms: Likely Organisms: Predominantly Gram negatives and anaerobes Enterococci may also feature
Variations.antimicrobial:
Antimircobial & Dosage: Co-amoxiclav 1.2g iv tds
+/-
Gentamicin 5mg/kg/day iv od (based on patient history, previous antibiotic use, clinical assessment, etc.)
Or
Amoxicillin 1g iv qds
Plus
Gentamicin 5mg/kg/day iv od
Plus
Metronidazole 500mg iv tds
Variations.alternative:
Alternative Antimicrobial: Penicillin allergy (non anaphylaxis) Cefuroxime 1.5g iv tds
Plus
Metronidazole 500mg iv tds
+/-
Gentamicin 5mg/kg/day iv od

Penicillin allergy (anaphylaxis): Vancomycin 15mg/kg iv bd Plus Gentamicin 5mg/kg/day iv od Plus Metronidazole 500mg iv tds
Variations.comments:
Comments:Perform full septic screen
Seek advice from Consultant Microbiologist if necessary
Send intra-operative samples (preferably pus not swabs) for culture if surgical intervention performed

Variations.organisms: Likely Organisms: Varies: Antimicrobial resistant gram- negative bacilli and meticillin resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) more likely
Variations.antimicrobial:
Antimicrobial & Dosage: Piperacillin-tazobactam 4.5g iv tds
+/-
Gentamicin 5mg/kg/day iv od (base treatment choice on patient history, previous antibiotic use, microbiology results, clinical assessment, etc.)
Variations.comments: Comments: Always take blood cultures first. Empiric treatment guided by previous antimicrobial treatment and culture results to date (review MRSA status and consider addition of Vancomycin if known to be colonised with MRSA)

Variations.antimicrobial: Antimicrobial & Dosage: Benzylpenicillin 1.2-2.4g iv qds or Amoxicillin 500mg po tds
Variations.alternative: Alternative Antimicrobial: Penicillin allergy: Doxycycline 100mg po bd or Clindamycin 300-450 mg po qds

Variations.organisms:
Likely Organisms: Group A ß-Haemolytic Streptococcus (Strep pyogenes)
Staph. aureus
Variations.antimicrobial:
Antimircobial & Dosage: Mild (not systemically unwell) Flucloxacillin 500mg po qds Duration: 7 days

Moderate (signs of systemic toxicity or progressive cellulitis) Flucloxacillin 2g iv qds Duration: 10-14 days

Severe (rapidly progressive cellulitis with severe sepsis/shock) Discuss with Consultant Microbiologist as possibility of deeper infection such as necrotising fasciitis should be considered Duration: 10-14 days
Variations.alternative:
Alternative Antimicrobial: Mild Penicillin allergy (non-anaphylaxis): Cephalexin 500mg po tds

MRSA positive (or penicillin anaphylaxis): Doxycycline 100mg po bd or Clindamycin 450 mg po qds (if susceptible - check with microbiology laboratory)

ModerateMRSA positive or penicillin allergy: Vancomycin 15mg/kg iv bd
Variations.comments:
Comments: Investigations: Blood cultures (if systemic features), swab if exudates present, check CRP/ESR/WBC, demarcate on patients skin outer border of cellulitis, check MRSA status if in-patient or recent healthcare contact

Note flucloxacillin has activity against both meticillin sensitive S. aureus and ß- Haemolytic streptococci so addition of benzylpenicillin is not indicated Clindamycin associated with increased risk of Clostridium difficile associated diarrhoea – reserve its use to defined indications as set out in these guidelines

Variations.condition: Gas gangrene, Necrotising fasciitis and other serious soft tissue infection
Variations.organisms: Likely Organisms: Polymicrobial including Group A ß-Haemolytic Streptococcus, Anaerobic bacteria (e.g. Clostridium perfringens), etc.
Variations.comments: Comments: Systemic toxicity, severe pain, swelling, crepitus and necrosis are clinical signs. Seek urgent advice from surgeons and microbiologist. Operative specimens for culture essential.

Variations.antimicrobial: Antimicrobial & Dosage: Topical antiseptic solutions eg Chlorhexidine or Povidone Iodine and dressings usually sufficient. Topical antibiotics are not recommended
Variations.comments: Comments: Clinically non-infected ulcers should not be cultured Systemic antimicrobials only indicated if evidence of cellulitis or systemic infection. Use previous culture results as a guide.

Variations.antimicrobial: Antimicrobial & Dosage: Treat as cellulitis MILD, MODERATE or SEVERE as above
Variations.alternative: Alternative Antimicrobial:Treat as cellulitis MILD, MODERATE or SEVERE as above
Variations.comments: Comments:Antibiotics may not be necessary: surgical drainage and/or topical antiseptics may be sufficient.

Variations.organisms: Likely Organisms: S. aureus, Gram negative bacilli, Streptococci, Anaerobes
Variations.antimicrobial:
Antimicrobial & Dosage: Co-Amoxiclav 1.2g iv tds

OR

Amoxicillin 1g iv tds Plus Gentamicin 5mg/kg iv od Plus Metronidazole 500mg iv tds

Duration: 5-7 days
Variations.alternative:
Alternative Antimicrobial: Penicillin allergy (non anaphylaxis): Cefuroxime 1.5g iv tds Plus Metronidazole 500mg iv tds

Penicillin allergy (anaphylaxis): Contact Consultant Microbiologist to discuss
Variations.comments:
Comments: Investigations: Blood cultures, swab if exudates present, CRP/ESR/WBC

Investigations: Blood cultures, swab if exudates present, CRP/ESR/WBC

Pus or tissue are more useful than swabs.

Variations.organisms: Likely Organisms: Wide range of flora including Pasteurella multocida and Capnocytophaga canimorsus
Variations.alternative:
Alternative Antimicrobial: Penicillin allergy (non anaphylaxis) Cefuroxime axetil 500 mg po bd Plus Metronidazole 400mg po tds

Penicillin allergy (anaphylaxis) Doxycycline 200mg po STAT then 100mg po bd plus Metronidazole 400mg po tds
Variations.comments:
Comments: Assess tetanus and rabies risk. Antibiotic prophylaxis may not be indicated for all cases.
Antibiotic prophylaxis advised for – puncture wound, bite involving hand, foot, face, joint, tendon, ligament, immunocompromised, diabetic, elderly, asplenic.

Variations.organisms: Likely Organisms: Wide range of mouth flora including viridans streptococci, staphylococci and Haemophilus spp.
Variations.alternative:
Alternative Antimicrobial: Penicillin allergy (non anaphylaxis) Cefuroxime axetil 500 mg po bd Plus Metronidazole 400mg po tds

Penicillin allergy (anaphylaxis) Doxycycline 200mg po STAT then 100mg po bd plus Metronidazole 400mg po tds
Variations.comments: Comments: Antibiotic prophylaxis advised. Risk assess for relevant blood borne viruses e.g. hepatitis B/C, HIV

Variations.organisms: Likely Organisms: Predominantly gram- positive organisms (e.g. Staphylococus aureus, Beta haemolytic streptococci)
Variations.alternative: Alternative Antimicrobial: Penicillin allergy/MRSA positive: Discuss with microbiologist
Variations.comments: Comments:Tissue or pus specimen from ulcer to be sent for culture and sensitivity (here and below rationalise treatment based on c+s). Always review previous culture results as this will guide therapy. Management includes wound care – clean, debride (antibiotics do not penetrate necrotic tissue) and offload pressure. Discuss care with endocrinology team

Variations.condition: Clinical Condition: Infected deep ulcer/ infected ulcer with mild (<2cm) cellulitis
Variations.organisms: Likely Organisms: Predominantly gram- positive organisms (e.g. Staphylococus aureus, Beta haemolytic streptococci)*
Variations.antimicrobial:
Antimircobial & Dosage: Flucloxacillin 500mg po qds*

Duration: 10-14 days (duration depends on extent of tissue injury involvement, adequacy of debridement and wound vasculature)
Variations.alternative:
Alternative Antimicrobial: Penicillin allergy/MRSA positive: Discuss with microbiologist
*If chronic ulcers, recent antibiotic use and foot ischaemia or gangrene consider polymicrobial aetiology and need for co-amoxiclav instead of flucloxacillin
Variations.comments:
Comments: As above
Patient may require IV antibiotics.
Contact microbiologist to discuss risk assessment regarding ciprofloxacin use in case of suspected pseudomonal infection.

Variations.condition: Clinical Condition: Infected foot ulcer with severe (>2cm) cellulitis
Variations.antimicrobial: Antimicrobial & Dosage: Flucloxacillin 2g iv qds Plus Ciprofloxacin 400mg iv bd Plus Metronidazole 500mg iv tds. Duration: 14 days (duration depends on extent of tissue injury involvement, adequacy of debridement and wound vasculature)
Variations.alternative: Alternative Antimicrobial: Penicillin allergy/MRSA positive: Vancomycin 15mg/kg iv bd Plus Ciprofloxacin 400mg iv bd Plus Metronidazole 500mg iv tds.
Variations.comments:
Comments: Ulcer debridement and send tissue sample or pus to microbiology.

If the patient has a past history of C. difficile contact the microbiologist regarding an alternative to ciprofloxacin for antibiotic therapy.

Variations.condition: Clinical Condition: Infected foot ulcer with suspected osteomyelitis
Variations.antimicrobial:
Antimircobial & Dosage: Flucloxacillin 2g iv qds Plus Ciprofloxacin 400mg iv bd Plus Metronidazole 500mg iv tds.
Duration: 8 weeks – 3 months (duration depends on acute or chronic presentation).
Variations.alternative: Alternative Antimicrobial: Penicillin allergy/MRSA positive: Vancomycin 15mg/kg iv bd Plus Ciprofloxacin 400mg iv bd Plus Metronidazole 500mg iv tds
Variations.comments:
Comments: Orthopaedic consultation regarding the need for bone biopsy and bone culture and in the setting of chronic osteomyelitis the need for bone debridement
Discuss treatment plan with microbiologist
